answers.author: Randy Webster
answers.text:
City of Portland, Oregon video records all City Council formal meetings and work-sessions, and posts to web in about a day or two. Total transparency and simple. Anyone can watch and play back to their hearts content. Also, closed captioning is included in real time, on a video monitor overhead, so this helps with accessibility. See Portland Online.

Hi, 
Thank you for your question on handling news media who miss meetings and still want to be filled in. I was able to find an article that discusses the city manager's role in keeping the news media informed, although they specifically were discussing when media is critical of the local government. I hope you are able to find the answer given in the article useful. It might be possible to write up a single summary and sent that to all media outlets so the treatment is equal and you only need to respond once. 
icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/2513
I hope other city managers and local government officials are able to chime in and provide you with first hand first hand experiences of how they deal with this issue ethically. 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

answers.author: Kate Rusch
answers.text:
We live-stream and record all meetings (and other educational programs) for members of the public/media to watch at their convenience: estes.org/videos  For us, this has resolved 99% of the problem you mentioned. 
Our Town Clerk also provides a brief after-action report the week following the meeting: estes.org/boardsandmeetings

answers.author: Toby Cotter
answers.text:
You might want to look into Granicus or similar companies that provide streaming services. Keep in mind that some media outlets just don't have the resources to send someone to every meeting. The national movement is placing all agenda packets online and streaming the meetings - no matter the size of the local government. This helps the media. But more importantly, it helps your residents.

author: [Anonymous]
text:
We have some news media outlets that seem to have difficulty, for whatever reason, attending our Board meetings; however, they also want us to discuss with them before or after a Board meeting what will be or has been discussed and/or acted upon.  We will be posting our meeting packets online beginning next meeting in an effort to help deal with this situation (and to provide information to the public, as well, of course); however, I'm sure they'll still want to go over what happened at the Board meeting afterwards.
While we certainly don't have anything to hide, I also don't believe that's our/my job to give a detailed account of what happened just because the news media can't or doesn't want to attend our Board meetings.  Has anyone dealt with this kind of situation and, if so, how did you handle it?  Thanks in advance for your assistance.
title: Handling The News Media
